b'This is the nine billion dollar check that may have saved Morgan Stanley. 12 years ago, markets were in turmoil, and like many businesses we searched for outside investors to help us get through the crisis. On the cusp of closing a deal to sell around 20% of our firm to MUFG, we ran into one final problem: Financial institutions in the U.S. that could facilitate a wire transfer from Tokyo would be closed for #ColumbusDay, while stock markets would be open, leaving the possibility that a significant amount of value could be wiped out before the cash injection stabilized our firm\xe2\x80\x99s finances. The solution? Write a check for nine billion dollars and deliver it in person. It was tense, but it worked. It renewed our existing partnership with MUFG which continues to this day. And it makes a great story. #MorganStanleyat85'

b'The U.S. Committee for the Care of European Children was convened by First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt in June 1940, with the intent of evacuating Jewish children from Europe during World War II. Morgan Stanley founder Harold Stanley quickly volunteered to lead a fundraising campaign in New York, which garnered the equivalent of $27MM today. Roosevelt wrote \xe2\x80\x9cI am thankful beyond words that it is going to be possible to do something for these European children.\xe2\x80\x9d The efforts resulted in the relocation of about 300 children to the U.S. Its operation ended when Hitler\xe2\x80\x99s troops invaded southern France in 1942, though it continued to rescue children in Spain and Portugal. #MorganStanleyat85'

b'A message on racial injustice and our way forward as a firm, from Morgan Stanley Chairman and CEO James Gorman: 
This week will not be easily forgotten in history, and it shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be. God-willing, it will be seen as a turning point in race relations. The pain, fear, sadness and anger felt by the Black community, and also by the vast majority of people globally, is palpable.

So what can we do?

Morgan Stanley\xe2\x80\x99s Black Managing Directors sent out a memo to express their hurt and pain on behalf of our Black community and to be there as leaders by collectively contributing to the @NAACP_ldf. I applaud their leadership. 
As a Firm we can do more, and we will do the following:

1.  Carol Greene-Vincent, Head of Global Internal Audit, will join Morgan Stanley\xe2\x80\x99s Operating Committee, the most senior governing body of this Firm. I was planning on having her join at the end of 2020, but I have accelerated her appointment to June 30.

2.  Susan Reid, Global Head of Diversity and Inclusion, will join Morgan Stanley\xe2\x80\x99s Management Committee as of June 30.

3.  In her elevated role, Susan will create a new Institute of Inclusion, modelled after our successful Institute of Sustainable Investing. It will have an independent advisory board that I will chair. Among many things, it will be responsible for setting policy, putting in place metrics, coordinating our internal and external voice, and overseeing the mentoring, development and promotion of our diverse employees. The Institute will be properly funded, initially with $25 million, to ensure it can successfully complete its mission.

4.  Just as our Black Managing Directors have contributed to the @NAACP_ldf, the Firm will make a donation of $5 million. In addition, the Firm will match dollar for dollar U.S. employee contributions to the Fund. 
5.  We\xe2\x80\x99ve added a new fifth value to our core values. While Committing to Diversity and Inclusion is implied in \xe2\x80\x9cDo the Right Thing,\xe2\x80\x9d it is time to make it explicit.

I urge all employees, whatever their race, color or political persuasion, to embrace these changes as we try to do our bit to make Morgan Stanley the place of choice to work for anyone of any background.'

I kept piling things for next week while weeks turned into months and months turned into a year and BAM! - I am a year older now.
In 2020, whenever I catch myself making these excuses I will remind myself of the beautiful things that happened before, all because I could break past the mental restrictions I had created. It's all about taking the first step. 
If I want to travel somewhere - I will start by researching all about the place.
If I want to learn a new coding language - I will start by fixing a time slot for that purpose.
If I want to avoid wasting my time on social media - I will put the apps in the hidden folder. 
Success always lies outside our comfort zone and this year I will break the habit of keeping things for \xe2\x80\x98someday'\xe2\x80\x9d
#MorganStanley"
